content.webTitle: Salsa Celtica: The Tall Islands – review

fields.headline: Salsa Celtica: The Tall Islands – review
fields.bodyText: Eighteen years ago, there was an historic session in an Edinburgh bar that included the trumpeter Toby Shippey, a Chilean guitarist, and the late, bravely experimental Martyn Bennett. They wanted to try mixing Celtic and Latin themes, and the result was Salsa Celtica, a band that now has a following among salsa dancers in Latin America and New York, as well as among British folk enthusiasts. Their new album features 17 musicians, including Shippey, from Scotland, Cuba, Ireland, Argentina and England. The opening track Descarga Gaélica sets the mood. Congas and timbale provide the backing for Megan Henderson and Kathleen MacInnes, whose rousing demonstration of rapid-fire Scottish Gaelic "mouth music" is intercut with a salsa chorus and trumpet workout. Elsewhere, there are sturdy Cuban vocals from Ricardo Fernandez Pompa, and jigs and reels given a Latin edge. This is a confident, exuberant fusion set that works.
